author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: There are few things more satisfying than the sense of belonging.
title: God With Us (Part 3)

sections.text: Read

There are few things more satisfying than the sense of belonging. In fact, what makes life so difficult and disappointing is that we almost always feel more or less out of place in this world. But remember the quote from C. S. Lewis. “If I find in myself a desire which no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that I was made for another world.” Lewis captures the sense of longing that we all feel and God’s word confirms it. We were made for the presence of God. We were created by his hand and recreated by his Spirit to belong to him.

The Bible begins with God making a world in which he could dwell with his people. Our rebellion separates us from his presence, the very place to which all our longings point. Jesus came and lived the life we should have lived. He died the death we deserved because of our sin. He rose to conquer death for us, and he sits at the right hand of the Father interceding for us now
Because of Jesus, we are reconciled to God through faith

But there is more to come. The story is not over. And though the end has been written, it’s not really the end. For those who are in Christ, our best days are always ahead because we were made to live forever on the earth in God’s presence

The joy of Christmas comes from remembering that what our hearts truly need and long for is nothing less than God himself. And this is exactly what he has given us. There is nothing greater than God, therefore there is no greater gift he could give us than himself. Because of Jesus’ first coming, we can know Immanuel, God with us, here and now through the presence of his indwelling Spirit. And when he returns in the flesh, we will know the pure bliss of having all our longings satisfied in his presence forever!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: God’s ultimate plan is to dwell with us for all eternity
title: God With Us (Part 2)

sections.text: Read

God’s promise to dwell with his people is a promise to dwell in his people. As the prophet Jeremiah foretold, God intended to write his instruction on the hearts of his people. In a broken world where no one seeks to do God’s will without external coercion, the promise was that one day the desire to obey would be as natural and effortless as our beating hearts. Can you imagine a version of yourself hat only desires what God desires and always delights to please him? That is what God intends, but it does not happen unless he himself does something in us.

As Jeremiah told of what God would do in the hearts of his people, so Ezekiel told of how God would accomplish this. It is only by the Spirit of God that we can even want to do what God requires. True obedience begins and ends at the level of our desires. This is why God’s promise to dwell with us included the giving of a new heart. It is the work of the Holy Spirit that accomplishes this in us. And it is the Holy Spirit who marks us as belonging to God.
God’s ultimate plan is to dwell with us for all eternity

But here and now, he has chosen to dwell with us through his word and his Spirit. This is how we come to know the LORD’s presence and power daily. As we read, listen to, and obey the Scriptures, the Spirit of God moves in our lives. To neglect the word of God is to deny the power of God in our lives. If we are to truly appreciate Jesus’ incarnation and genuinely long for his return, then we must seek to commune with him through the means that he has given us. The promise of “God with us” is only realized when we pursue Christ through his word and in dependence upon his Spirit.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: The promise of God’s presence is perhaps the most prevalent theme in Scripture.
title: God With Us (Part 1)

sections.text: Read

The promise of God’s presence is perhaps the most prevalent theme in Scripture. The Bible begins with God creating the world to be a home in which he can dwell with mankind. Sin caused a rift between God and man. But God promised to repair all that was broken and recover all that was lost
Christ came to bring us back into God’s presence
When the LORD made a covenant with Abraham, he bound himself permanently not only to Abraham alone but all of his offspring
And who are Abraham’s offspring?
The apostle Paul wrote that it is those who belong to Christ who are the true offspring of Abraham

So it is those whose faith is in Jesus who are the recipients of God’s promise to Abraham. This is the promise that they will be his people and he will be their God.  The promise of God’s presence was not only fulfilled in Christ taking on flesh. God’s promise to be with us was established through his covenant with Abraham. And by faith in Jesus, anyone can become an heir of this promise. Since Christ is the truest expression of God’s presence and it is in him that all God's promises are fulfilled

, to be united to Christ in faith is to walk through this life continually in his presence. No matter what life brings, no matter how dark the world gets, God is with all who are his by faith in Jesus.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: There is no reason not to believe in the faithfulness of God...
title: Promise Made, Promise Kep

sections.text: Read

Ahaz was king in Judah. He was a descendent of David, but Syria (a superior military power) was threatening not only his reign but seemingly God’s promise to have a son of David on the throne of Judah forever
Ahaz was afraid

so the LORD sent the prophet Isaiah to the king and invited Ahaz to ask the LORD for a sign as assurance that his promise would hold true. But Ahaz stubbornly refused. At first glance, it seems like humility. Ahaz responded by saying that he did not want to test the LORD. There are many places in Scripture that warn about asking for signs and testing the LORD, but this was a genuine invitation from God himself. Yet, Ahaz was not willing to trust the LORD.

We may think Ahaz a fool, but how many times do we ask God to show us his will and then fail to follow through in faith when he responds to our request? Often, this is because we already know what we want; we just want God to affirm our preconceived desires.

The sign that God offered Ahaz was a child whose name would be “Immanuel, God with us.” What more do we need? We have seen the coming of this promised king. There is no reason not to believe in the faithfulness of God, for at the right time he sent his Son to redeem us from the oppression of sin and claim us as his own beloved children

If ever we doubt God, we need only remember the promise made and the promise kept: Immanuel, God with us. Advent reminds us that we dare not put our hope in anything less than the certain promises of God fulfilled in Jesus Christ.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: This Christmas, don’t settle for merely commemorating a quaint story about a sweet, little baby born to a virgin girl in a stable.
title: This Christmas

sections.text: Read
“She will bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus, ‘for he will save his people from their sins”

Many times, Christmas is disappointing because we are doing it wrong. We get distracted by all the peripheral trappings, and we miss the whole point of it all. Of course, we all love the parties, the gifts, the time with friends and family. But if we don’t keep the main thing the main thing, then everything else loses its meaning. Here is the heart of Christmas, the heart of Scripture, the heart of redemptive history: Jesus came to save his people from their sins. His very name means “to save.” Remember the promise back in Genesis 3:15? God was pronouncing a curse on the serpent because he had deceived Adam and Eve into rebelling against God. Yet, embedded in this curse was the promise that the “seed of the woman” would come and crush the head of the serpent. It’s clear that the offspring himself would sustain injury because the LORD also said that the serpent would “bruise his heel.”

But how would the promised descendent accomplish this salvation? For centuries, the people of God studied to understand the true meaning of this promise, but we now have the benefit of knowing the full story. The offspring that was promised in the midst of humanity’s worst, is none other than Jesus Christ. He came to crush the head of the serpent who is Satan. He accomplished this not by coming in brute strength but in humility and weakness. Through his death, Jesus paid the penalty for sin and stripped sin of its power over us. “He was pierced for our wrongdoing; he was crushed for our evil desires; upon him was the punishment that brought us peace, and by his wounds we are saved.” And all this was God’s plan from the beginning

This Christmas, don’t settle for merely commemorating a quaint story about a sweet, little baby born to a virgin girl in a stable. Understand the true meaning of it. This child was born to die. He left his throne in heaven to be born in the likeness of mankind so that he could take on not only our human frailty and weakness but our guilt and shame from sin. We have been delivered from God’s just punishment toward our sin. Jesus’ perfect obedience to the Father qualifies him to make full payment for our sin. His resurrection and ascension is the Father’s stamp of approval to show that Jesus’ death was truly enough to cover our sins (past, present, and future). As someone has said, we have been saved from sin’s penalty; we are being saved from sin’s power; and one day we will be saved from sin’s presence. This Christmas, we celebrate Christ’s first coming which sealed our salvation. This Christmas, we anticipate Christ’s second coming in which our salvation will be fully and finally realized. This Christmas, keep the main thing the main thing.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: What we think Christmas is will determine how we observe it and whether we enjoy it.
title: The Origin Story

sections.text: Read

What we think Christmas is will determine how we observe it and whether we enjoy it. The traditional word for this season is actually Advent, and it means “coming.” Historically, Christians have observed the Advent season by celebrating not only  Christ’s first coming but also anticipating his second coming. So, to truly experience the meaning of Christmas is to remember how and why Jesus came in the flesh and to reflect on his promises to return.

More than the accomplishments we achieve, our heritage is part of who we are. This can be disappointing if we don’t come from an “ideal” family situation (whatever that looks like). It can also be a dangerous source of pride for us if we put too much emphasis on our background. Our ethnic and familial heritage is part of who we are, but it is not the whole of who we are meant to be. Regardless of your earthly heritage, the history recorded in Matthew chapter one is important for you. This is your ancestry, your story, if you are in Christ. So read it as if it is your own family history! And if you are not yet united to Christ, this can become your story through faith in him.

My hope is that by reading these short devotions, you will see the wisdom of God’s perfect plan of redemption brought about through imperfect people. I hope you will recapture the wonder of Christ’s birth, not as mere happenstance but as a promise fulfilled by the God who oversees all of history. I hope that you will better comprehend how all of Scripture points to Jesus. And I hope that this will help you remember the true meaning of the Advent season as you look back to Jesus’ first coming and long for his return!
Enjoy and Merry Christmas!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: The origin story of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. Matthew 1:1
title: The Promised Descendant

sections.text: Read

David was the greatest king of Israel, the one who ruled from a heart that feared God above all others. The tiny nation of Israel never knew such blessing, security, and prominence as when David was king. David even became the very standard by which all other kings in Israel were measured because only under David did Israel rightly worship the LORD. In fact, what it meant to be a “son of David” was not merely to be his descendant but to rule in the fear of the Lord the way that David did. In 2 Samuel 7:16, God promised King David, “And your house and your kingdom shall be made sure forever before me. Your throne shall be established forever.” How could this be? How would David’s rule last forever? Only through his greater Son. Christ is the fulfillment of God’s promise to King David. The Scripture is clear that David’s righteous rule was always pointing forward to a coming King who would rule perfectly and permanently
When God said to Abraham, “…in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed…” it was through a particular descendant that God intended to make good on this promise

It was the Jews who were the chosen people of God from all the nations of the earth, but through Jesus, God expanded his chosen family to include people from every nation, every language, every tribe. Now, through faith in Jesus Christ, anyone, regardless of their ethnic or family heritage, can become a child of God. "He came to his own, and his own people did not receive him. But to all who did receive him, who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God, who were born not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man but of God"

As the son of Abraham, Jesus is the one through whom anyone can become a child of God. As the son of David, Jesus is the promised ruler who has inaugurated and will establish a new kingdom of peace and prosperity that will last forever! In Jesus, the Light of the world has broken through the darkness of sin and suffering in this world. No matter our circumstances this Advent season, we can celebrate with joy and hope, knowing that the hero we need has already come! And because he came the first time to redeem his fallen creation, we can trust that he will come again to restore it fully and finally!

Heavenly Father, thank you for sending us your Son, who identifies with us in our weaknesses but also rules over us in the strength of your steadfast love! Help us to be in awe that you would come down to us in this way! AMEN!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Abraham was the father of Isaac, and Isaac the father of Jacob, and Jacob the father of Judah and his brothers… Matthew 1:2
title: No One Chooses There Relatives…But God Does

sections.text: Read

Connecting Jesus to the family tree of Abraham ensured Jewish readers that their Messiah was “one of them.” When the earth was filled with wickedness and sin, God chose not to scrap it all and start over but to work through a man and his family. God made a promise to Abraham that from him would come a great nation (Israel), through whom he would bless all nations

The Scripture frequently refers to the LORD as “the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob” because these were the sons of promise through whom God would bring ultimate salvation to the world. These were the men with whom God made his covenant. A covenant is a promise that binds and reinforces an already-established relationship. It is accompanied by a physical sign (usually involving blood). And when the LORD revealed himself to Moses for the first time, he identified himself as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob and said that this is how he will be remembered throughout all generations
It was not because these men were great that God chose them. Abraham deceived Pharaoh and pretended his wife was his sister out of fear for his own life. Isaac did the same

Jacob was a regular deceiver, but he fathered Judah along with 11 other brothers who would ultimately make up the entire nation of Israel. God chose to bind himself to these men and their families, even to the point of being known as “the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.” Why? Because God wanted to be known as the God who uses the weak things of the world to shame the strong and the foolish things to shame the wise

No one can explain why or how such a family tree could bring about the Savior of the world, but this is exactly the point. Jesus did not come from a line of perfect men but from a messy and dysfunctional family. And he didn’t come for those who have it all together either. He said himself, “I did not come to call the righteous but sinners to repentance.” The apostle Paul wrote that “all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God.” Jesus came for you! He came for all those who recognize their total need of him. God sent his Son into the world not because we deserve him but because He is good! He has bound himself to us through Christ as the sacrifice for our sins! God was not ashamed to be identified with Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, or Judah. And if we are in Christ, he is not ashamed to be identified with us either. How amazing!
Heavenly Father, thank you for showing us that you are enough when we are not. Thank you for binding yourself to us and choosing us by sending your Son Jesus as the sacrifice for our sins. AMEN!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: …and Judah the father of Perez and Zerah by Tamar, and Perez the father of Hezron, and Hezron the father of Ram…” Matthew 1:3
title: A Broken Family Tree

sections.text: Read

My wife has referred to the stories in Genesis as one big soap opera. Unfortunately, it's much worse because it’s a true story, and it reflects the real-life situations that happen when people choose sin and self rather than to fear the LORD and trust his plan. In the ancient Near East, when a young woman’s husband died it was understood that the deceased’s brother (or next closest male relative) would redeem her by taking her as his wife. This provided support for the widow and ensured that the family tree would persist. This, coupled with God’s command to Adam, Noah, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob to “be fruitful and multiply,” shows just how defiant Judah was being when he failed to give his youngest son to Tamar. We might think her way of getting back at Judah was perverse. While the Bible does not condone Tamar’s actions, the narrative is clearly meant to shame Judah for not trusting God’s plan and to show God’s faithfulness to work out his plan despite the crooked actions of those he uses.

The LORD had a plan and purpose for Tamar, though she was shamed and neglected. It was not common practice in that time and culture to include women in ancestry records. What’s more, we would never expect the ancestry of Jesus Christ to be so scandalous. This makes the story of the Bible and the particularities of Matthew's genealogy quite revolutionary. The human authors of Scripture never try to cover up the drama. All the “dirty laundry” is out there for everyone to see, and God intended it to be this way. It was through the mess of Judah’s family drama that God would bring the royal line of King David. When Jacob blessed his 12 sons before his death, Judah received the most significant promise. It was the promise that from Judah’s line would come a king who would rule all the nations forever
It was through a perverse and sinful situation that God would bring the perfect and sinless Savior of the world! This broken family actually led to the One who makes all families whole!

What an amazing God that he can bring such beauty from brokenness! How encouraging for the rest of us who know that we are messed up like Judah and Tamar. Some of us may have come from families with similar drama or dysfunction, even abuse. But we are never beyond God’s ability and delight to make something beautiful out of an ugly situation. It’s been said that God only uses broken people because ultimately that is all he has to work with. But it’s also because that is how good he really is!
Father, thank you that you use us in spite of ourselves. Help us to see beyond our mess and trust that you are working out your plan for our good and for your glory! AMEN!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: …and Judah the father of Perez and Zerah by Tamar, and Perez the father of Hezron, and Hezron the father of Ram…” Matthew 1:4
title: The Noble Nobodies

sections.text: Read

Little is known of Aminadab or Nashon. Amminadab was Aaron’s father-in-law and his name in Hebrew means “my kinsmen are noble.” Nashon was the chief prince of Judah’s tribe when Israel was in the wilderness organizing her armies. These men represent the royal and warrior nature of the tribe of Judah and without them, there would have been no expectation of a strong Savior King. They are scarcely mentioned, but mentioned, nonetheless, in their relation to Jesus. Did you catch that? Their ultimate significance is not in being known but in their connection to Jesus. It is no different for us. We can only find our ultimate identity and significance in being united with King Jesus!

Nothing in God’s plan is insignificant. He uses people, places, and things within his creation to bring about the redemption and perfection of his creation. He used Aram (or Ram), Aminadab, and Nashon to bring about and point to the Savior of the world. The celebration of Advent is a celebration that God uses the nobodies, the poor, the weak, the seemingly insignificant to show his own power and glory.

We may never know what will become of our descendants, but we cannot underestimate God’s plan to use us to shape future generations. We may not be remembered by the coming generations, but we are called by God to cultivate whatever he has given us for his own glory. Your life, your family, your home is your little “kingdom” to oversee on behalf of the Great King to whom it ultimately belongs! And even if you haven’t had the privilege of bearing and raising children, you have the great privilege of modeling and reproducing genuine faith for whomever God has placed in your life. The world may not remember us, but by God’s grace they will remember the Savior to whom we point! And ultimately, we know that the Creator and Savior of the world knows us, sees us, and loves us. He remembers us even if no one else does!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: …and Salmon the father of Boaz by Rahab, and Boaz the father of Obed by Ruth, and Obed the father of Jesse…
title: Unlikely Vessels

sections.text: Read

No one could have anticipated this. Two women, one a prostitute and the other a Moabite. Both of them came from pagan backgrounds that did not honor Israel’s God as the one true God. Yet, both women demonstrated their reverence for the LORD. And these are the vessels through whom God brought his eternal Son into the world! This shows the infinite wisdom and grace of God!
Rahab feared the LORD because she and all of Jericho had heard what the God of Israel had done in parting the Red Sea and causing his people to conquer all their enemies

She acted upon her knowledge of God by protecting the two spies of Israel at great risk of her own wellbeing. Just when it seemed that God’s promise of land to Abraham’s descendants would not come to be, the LORD made a way through a most unlikely servant and his people conquered their enemy. Rehab assimilated into Israel by marrying Salmon. Their son Boaz would become the kinsman redeemer and husband of another young foreign woman.
Ruth was a Moabite woman. Ethnically, the Moabites were related to the Israelites

sections.Text: However, they were a pagan nation, which means they did not worship Yahweh as the one true God. Yet, Ruth had married an Israelite, and after she became a widow, she stayed with her mother-in-law Naomi rather than go back to the familiar land of her own people. She risked never remarrying in the land of the Israelites because of her love for Naomi and reverence for the LORD

sections.text: This foreigner became the great grandmother of the greatest earthly king ever to sit on the throne of Jerusalem! Just when it seemed that God’s promise to Judah was in jeopardy, the LORD preserved Judah’s royal line through a most unlikely servant.

In the story of Rehab, it is Joshua who spares her life and her family. Joshua is a form of Yeshua meaning “to save or deliver.” The English version of this name is Jesus. Boaz shows himself to be gracious, compassionate, and righteous to rescue two widows from poverty and hopelessness (something Boaz’ ancestor Judah had been unwilling to do for Tamar

As Joshua spared the lives of Rahab and her family, so God has spared the lives of all who trust in his Son. As Boaz redeemed and restored Ruth and Naomi at great cost to himself, so Christ redeemed us by giving up his life for our sins. “He comes to make his blessing flow, far as the curse is found!”

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: …and Jesse the father of David the king.” Matthew 1:6
title: Longing For What Lasts

sections.text: Read

One of the things that makes the Christmas season (and life in general) so discouraging is that the things we enjoy about it are here one day and gone the next. If we experience joy at all it is only for a moment, and most of us have seen so many of our longings remain unfulfilled. But at some point, we need to ask whether our longings themselves are misplaced.

David was the king of all Israel. The kingdom was united. God had chosen him, anointed him, raised him up, and caused him to conquer all his enemies. But David longed to build a temple for the ark of the covenant. Up to this point, the ark had only ever dwelt in a temporary structure (tabernacle). This was the innermost part of the tabernacle, where the presence of the LORD dwelt. This allowed the God of Israel to dwell among his people but simultaneously conveyed that he himself is holy and could not be approached casually. To David, it didn’t seem right to live in an extravagant palace while the presence of the LORD himself resided in a tent. But when he set his mind to build a temple, the LORD said “No!” Yet, what God had in mind for David was better than anything he could have imagined!

2 Samuel 7 is one of the most important chapters in the Old Testament and perhaps the whole Bible. Here, God makes a covenant with David. The promise was three-fold. First, the LORD promised to give David rest from all his enemies

This obviously didn’t mean that David wouldn’t have any more enemies but that any threat, foreign or domestic, would be shut down. Second, David’s son Solomon would be the one to build a temple where the people of God could meet with the LORD regularly and have their sins atoned for through their sacrifices
And third, David’s family would rule on the throne of Jerusalem forever

Today, we know for a fact that there is no king sitting on a throne in Jerusalem. So, does this mean that God’s promise to David is broken. Not a chance! The LORD’s promise to David was fulfilled finally and fully in Jesus Christ. Through his death, Christ conquered the enemy of sin by taking sin’s punishment upon himself. That includes all of David’s sin, all of my sin, and all of your sin too! What is more, through his resurrection from the dead Jesus has conquered not mere earthly enemies but death itself. He now sits enthroned in the heavens at the right hand of God. But there is more to it than this. Even now, we await his return when he will come and sit on the throne in the New Jerusalem
Ultimately, the kingdom that was promised to David is the kingdom for which we ourselves are still waiting. It’s the everlasting kingdom for which we were made

Hold fast! It is coming! The real question is, “Do you long for it?” The true path to perfect peace, joy, and hope is to long for something better than what we have settled for. Long for what lasts. Long for the things that God has promised. Experience them now and forever by trusting in the eternal one who alone can deliver on these promises!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Yet, God still chose to dwell with his people.
title: Where We Meet God

sections.text: Read
God made a promise to King David that his son Solomon would build the temple for the LORD’s presence to dwell among his people

But this promise actually stretches back all the way to the Garden in Eden. From the beginning of creation, God’s plan was to dwell with mankind on the earth. That sounds crazy, right? God is above and beyond time and space; why would he want to live with mankind? Yet, this is the story of the Bible. God created man and woman and placed them in a garden, a sanctuary where they would enjoy his presence continually. God looked on all of his creation and he loved every bit of it. But when sin entered the garden, Adam and Eve were kicked out as a consequence.

Yet, God still chose to dwell with his people. He instructed Moses and the Israelites to build a tabernacle where they could meet with God. He allowed David’s son Solomon to construct the great Temple in Jerusalem, which became the center of all Jewish worship of God. The design of both the tabernacle in the wilderness and the temple in Jerusalem closely resembled the elements of the Garden in Eden. This would remind every worshiper that creation itself was intended to be a home for God and his people. But it would also remind them that God is holy and can only be encountered on his own terms. When the apostle John writes that “the Word became flesh and dwelt among us,” the word he uses for “dwelt” is the same Greek word for tabernacle. This is no coincidence. John intended to communicate that Jesus is the true Garden, the true Tabernacle, and the true Temple. Jesus is the place where we meet God himself!

In Jesus, we see a God who wants to dwell with his people. In Jesus, we see a God who comes down in the flesh. Only through Jesus can we see the one true God. Only through Jesus can we have our sins forgiven and approach his holiness. And only through Jesus can we dwell with this God forever!

“And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying, “Behold, the dwelling place of God is with man. He will dwell with them, and they will be his people, and God himself will be with them as their God.”

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: We can trust that God will make good on his promise...
title: Dark Times, Brightest Hope

sections.text: Read

After Solomon’s reign in Jerusalem, the nation of Israel was divided into two main sections, the tribes of Judah and Benjamin in the south and the remaining ten tribes to the north. There was much that led up to this crisis, not least of all the sin of Solomon and others who did not rule according to the LORD’s wisdom. They sought the worldly counsel of those who craved power and success
Many of them acted wickedly in the eyes of the LORD and did not shepherd God’s people as they were meant to do. Yet, the division of the kingdom was actually the plan of God
And it was in these dark centuries of a divided kingdom that some of the most well-known prophecies emerged.
It was in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah that the prophet Isaiah foretold a descendant of Jesse who would rule in perfect righteousness and peace

It was in the midst of Judah’s wickedness that the promise of the perfect King came. This is a reminder to us that there is ultimately no political, social, or economic solution for the issues that we face in our world. It is a reminder that in the darkest of times, the promises of God shine brightest. Sin may bring about God’s judgment, but for those who trust in the LORD, this judgment brings about desperation, desperation brings us to genuine repentance, repentance stirs in us longing, and longing causes us to seek satisfaction in the LORD alone.

We may look at our world and be totally disheartened. We may feel overwhelmed because of circumstances that we cannot understand or change. But the Advent season reminds us that God oversees all of history. It reminds us to cling to his certain promise of a King who one day will right all wrongs once and for all. We can trust that God will make good on his promise because Jesus has already come to right the greatest wrong, our sin. When he comes again, we will experience his total rule in all its fullness and perfection! AMEN!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: For many, Christmas is not the most wonderful time of the year.
title: Sing the Songs of Advent, Even Through Tears

sections.text: Read

For many, Christmas is not the most wonderful time of the year. It is a reminder that there will be empty seats at the table. It’s another source of financial strain or pressure to find the perfect gifts. It’s the mark of another year gone by and the reality that we can’t stop the passing of time, the aging of our bodies, or the rapid growth of our children. But the Psalms can offer a helpful release for those who need it this time of year because they neither diminish the harshness of life nor leave us to despair.

After hundreds of years of bad kings and a divided kingdom, both the northern kingdom (Israel) and the southern kingdom (Judah) found themselves under the rule of Nebuchadnezzar. This fierce king carried off most of the Jewish inhabitants and attempted to strip them of their heritage and even their faith in Yahweh. It would take 70 years for them to be able to return to their homeland, which meant that an entire generation would die in a foreign land

Religious and cultural identity became more difficult to maintain. Many, if not all, Jews wondered if the God who bound himself to their fathers Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob had abandoned them forever. Will God keep his promises? Does God really love us? These are the very circumstances in which Psalm 137 was written.
The Jews asked, “How can we sing the LORD’s song in a foreign land?”

We might say, “How can we sing ‘Joy to the World’ when all we feel inside is sorrow. It may seem there is no encouragement in this psalm. After all, it ends with the notion of Babylonian children being “dashed against the rocks”

But herein lies the hope. We as the people of God cannot allow ourselves to forget the promises of God or the things he has already brought us through. The Jews knew from the Scripture that God would ultimately deliver them
And they remembered his great deliverance in the past

This became the source of their continued hope and provided the resolve they needed to simply trust the LORD even when the situation was dark. It also gave them the confidence to pray and to sing even when they didn’t feel like it.

When we lift our eyes to the LORD, we inevitably have to get them off of ourselves. This frees us to have a godly perspective and trust that God is in control and that he cares for us. The reason we can trust him is that we have already seen his deliverance in the cross of Christ. There, Jesus freed us from the penalty of sin and the power of death. One day soon, he will come again to free us from their reality altogether! So, sing the song of Zion in a foreign land. Sing the songs of Advent that acknowledge the dark realities of this earthly life but also remind us of the glorious future that awaits those who trust in the coming King. AMEN!

sections.quote:
"Hail the heav’nly Prince of Peace!
Hail the Sun of Righteousness!
Light and life to all He brings,
Ris’n with healing in His wings.
Mild He lays His glory by,
Born that man no more may die;
Born to raise the sons of earth,
Born to give them second birth."

Hark! The Herald Angels Sing
- Charles Wesley

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: For many, Christmas is not the most wonderful time of the year.
title: Embrace Hard Things

sections.text: Read

Everyone loves to quote Jeremiah 29:11, but few actually understand the context in which this great promise emerged. Judah had been taken into captivity by Babylon. Throughout the Babylonian invasion there were many false prophets who were telling the people that it was not God’s plan for Jerusalem to fall, that Judah would always stand against foreign invasion. But these prophets only told the people what they wanted to hear. At best, it was wishful thinking on their part. At worst, this message was demonic in its source. This is a lesson for those of us who might resonate with teachers and preachers who tell us what we already want to hear. The Lord may not be in message so beware.

In reality, it was God’s plan that a large population of his people would be taken captive by Nebuchadnezzar. This is what he had spoken through Isaiah and Jeremiah. So, when the people became confused by contradictory messages, they needed a reminder. God told them to stay put, and trust his plan. Embrace the place that God has put you, even if it isn’t home. God’s instruction to his people was very simple. “Build houses and live in them; plant gardens and eat their produce. 6 Take wives and have sons and daughters; take wives for your sons, and give your daughters in marriage, that they may bear sons and daughters; multiply there, and do not decrease. 7 But seek the welfare of the city where I have sent you into exile, and pray to the Lord on its behalf, for in its welfare you will find your welfare”

he deportation of God’s people to Babylon made it seem like God was abandoning them. But Matthew’s genealogy reminds us that they continued to live life. In fact, they flourished in such a way that they continued to bear children, even in a culture that was dark and broken. The LORD sustained them, and the building of their families would ultimately lead to the birth of the promised Savior from God.

Whatever the hardship you face, don’t fight it! As the apostle Paul says 2 Corinthians, “For this light and momentary affliction is preparing for us an eternal weight of glory beyond all comparison.” Advent reminds us that even the hard things are a part of God’s plan. Embrace the hardship. Be faithful to what God has already revealed in his word. Rest in his goodness and trust him to reveal the full picture in time. What he has promised, he will do. We need not look any further than Jesus to remember that he is faithful and true.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Idolatry happens when we worship the gift over the Giver, the created over the Creator.
title: Have Yourself An Idolatrous Little Christmas?

sections.text: Read

Christmas is celebrated in all kinds of ways. There are pleasant and quaint traditions that make this time of year so enjoyable for many. But if we’re not careful, we will find ourselves worshiping the idea of Christmas without worshiping the Christ to whom it points. When we expect from Christmas what it hasn’t promised, then we are left disappointed with it. And it’s not because we expect too much from Christmas; it’s because we don’t expect enough!

Idolatry happens when we worship the gift over the Giver, the created over the Creator. It happens when we take good things that God has given us and make them ultimate. It happens when we expect from creation the kind of satisfaction and security that only God himself can provide. It also happens subtly when we worship our own ideas of who God is rather than the One who is revealed in Scripture.

Israel was sent into exile because of their idolatry. They sinned at various times either by worshiping false gods or by worshiping their own idea of who the true God is. When the consequences of their idolatry came in the form of Assyrian and Babylonian invasion, they foolishly trusted in other idolatrous nations to deliver them. Ironically, they looked to powers like Egypt, a nation that had previously enslaved them hundreds of years before

They forgot who they were as God’s people, and thus, they trusted in lesser powers to deliver them. It was in this context that an eternal King was promised. This King would establish his kingdom “to uphold justice with righteousness from this time forth and forevermore”
He would also restore the right worship of God by opening the eyes of those who are spiritually blinded by worshiping lesser gods

We are guilty of trusting other people, places, and things. We think that the next job promotion, the next degree, the next relationship, the next season of life is going to satisfy the deep longings of our hearts. But as Augustine said, “You O Lord have made us for yourself, and our hearts are restless until they find their rest in you.” We were created to “glorify God and enjoy him forever” (The Westminster Shorter Catechism, Question 1). This Christmas, enjoy the time with family and friends, the Christmas parties, the giving and receiving of gifts, the delicious food, and other traditions that make this time of year so special. But do not expect these things to satisfy your soul. That is something only Christ himself can do. These lesser things have value and meaning only in light of who Jesus is and what he has done to set you free from the enslavement of sin and idolatry. They are good gifts that should point us to the ultimate Gift and cause us to seek him with all our hearts!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: We wouldn’t naturally think of Genesis 3:15 as the quintessential Christmas passage.
title: The Seed of the Woman

sections.text: Read

We would expect Matthew to emphasize the davidic ancestry here at the end of the genealogy. After all, he started by calling Jesus “the son of David” and then traced this royal lineage all the way up to Joseph. But then, he breaks from this line and shows that Jesus actually wasn’t the direct biological descendant of David after all. Of course, even Mary and Joseph were distant relatives because they were both Jews and had a common ancestry that went back to Abraham. But it doesn’t diminish the reality of Matthew’s intentional language. Jesus was born of Mary, not Joseph
Unless we understand the unusual nature of this, we will miss its significance.

We wouldn’t naturally think of Genesis 3:15 as the quintessential Christmas passage. How many times have you read this verse to your kids on Christmas day? But this is where the promise of Christ begins. Right there in the garden, in the midst of pronouncing a curse on the Serpent, God simultaneously promised a Savior who would crush the Serpent’s head. And this Savior would be born of a woman. The language that God used would become unmistakeable; the Savior will be born of a virgin. The word used for “offspring” in Genesis 3:15 is the word for “seed.” Women do not have seed; men do. Yet, God says that the seed of the woman will crush the head of the Serpent. The answer to Adam and Eve’s rebellion against God (and all the rebellion since) would come through a chosen descendant.

Jesus was born as a man so as to genuinely identify with humanity. He was born of a virgin to show that he is not like any other human being; he is the God-man. The power of Satan lies in his ability to steal, kill, and destroy by tempting us to distrust the LORD

And this power is reinforced as he accuses us, highlighting our sin and shame. But the child born of a virgin has disarmed Satan of his greatest weapons. And he did this by taking our sin and shame upon himself
Satan’s accusations are now swallowed up in the reality that Christ has borne our punishment once and for all.

From the garden, Satan has continued to bruise the heel of Christ. Yet, in the cross, Christ has delivered the crushing blow to Satan’s head. Like any dead snake whose body continues to wriggle, though the head is removed, Satan continues to try to thwart God’s plan
But his attempts are pointless, and his time is short. The Seed of the woman has conquered him fully and finally through his death and resurrection.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: We do not live trying to work our way up to God.
title: Rest In God’s Perfect Schedule

sections.text: Read

In the Bible, the number seven is very important! It signifies completion or perfection or rest. God created the universe in six days and rested on the seventh to show that his work was finished and that it was good
He gave Israel a 7 day week, six of which they would work and on the 7th they would rest in God’s provision
Before the Jews were exiled to Babylon, God said that they would be captives there for 70 years, after which their families would return to the homeland

When Peter asked Jesus how many times a person should forgive, he assumed seven would be the answer. But Jesus responded, “I do not say seven but seventy-seven” showing that true forgiveness is everlasting
You get the point. Sevens in the Bible show us that something has been brought to its intended completion.
There is debate as to whether Matthew’s statement that there are 42 generations from Abraham to Jesus is valid

Doing the historical math, it would seem that some generations have been left out. But Matthews’s purpose is not to give a literal and detailed account of Jesus’ family tree. His purpose is to show that Jesus’ birth inaugurated the completion of the rest that was promised in all the generations before him. The generations from Abraham to Jesus that Matthew highlights add up to 42. That is 6 “seven’s.” Just as creation and the calendar week are incomplete without the seventh day of rest, so history would not be complete without the coming of Christ. This means that we are living in the completion of the history of the world and the fullness of God‘s kingdom.

We do not live trying to work our way up to God. We rest in the goodness of the God who came down to us! We may only see glimpses now, but we can have confidence that God is sovereign over all history and his plan is on schedule. Our task is to rest in Jesus as the fulfillment of all things. God has not forgotten his promises or given up on his people. He is working all things together for the good of his people and the glory of his reputation

For God’s people, there is no reason to fear the uncertainty of the future or the increasing decay of society or be anxious because of hard times. “For when the fullness of time had come, God sent forth his Son, born of woman, born under the law, to redeem those who were under the law so that we might receive adoption as sons”
Rest in the perfection of God’s schedule!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: It was necessary for Christ to be born in frail humanity since his purpose was to be the Savior of the world.
title: The Indwelling Holy Spirit

sections.text: Read

It was necessary for Christ to be born in frail humanity since his purpose was to be the Savior of the world. He had to be like us to the fullest degree. Hebrews 4 says that he identifies with our weaknesses in every way, “yet without sin”
But he also had to be set apart (holy) from humanity, distinct so as to be qualified to atone for the sins of humanity
Certainly, this meant living a life of perfect obedience to the Father

But to ensure that even his human birth was unique from all others, the Godhead determined from eternity past that Christ would be born of a virgin. And this happened because the Holy Spirit came upon Mary in a special way.

It’s incredible in itself that God would see fit to become subject to his creation, let alone that he would come in the form of a helpless child. But we can’t really comprehend what it meant for the young Mary to become pregnant by the miraculous working of the Holy Spirit. This is why Mary was so humbled by the reality that the promised Savior, the eternal Son of God would grow inside her belly. She knew that she had been chosen to carry the one who was promised to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob and whom the prophets had foretold for centuries
And as the child grew, so too did her union with him.

Every woman who has carried a child in her womb knows the unexplainable intimacy they feel during the season. And those who haven’t had this privilege may long to have it. But the promise of God is that we all can have this level of intimacy with Christ’s Spirit, whether we are a man or woman, rich or poor, barren or fertile. We all can know what it is to be one with Christ through the indwelling Holy Spirit. The apostle Paul writes, “Or do you not know that your body is a temple of the Holy Spirit within you, whom you have from God? You are not your own, for you were bought with a price. So glorify God in your body”

Jesus came as the true Temple, the place where we meet God. But when we turn from trusting in ourselves and trust in him, we become a temple (dwelling place) for God’s Spirit. The season of Advent and the story of Christmas are reminders that God came to dwell, not just with his people but in them

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: “...unless one is born again he cannot see the kingdom of God”
title: New Birth In the Spirit

sections.text: Read

The birth of the Savior through Mary is miraculous to be sure! But even more miraculous is the reality that through the Holy Spirit, God makes dead, dark hearts alive. God’s Spirit alone can make someone who had no interest in Jesus become a true lover of Jesus. Mary’s conception of Jesus by the Holy Spirit was a private thing. No one could testify to it because no one could actually see it. But when a person is made new by the Holy Spirit, everyone knows that something is different.
Jesus told Nicodemus that it wasn’t his religious efforts or intellect that would enable him to see the kingdom of God. The natural man does not understand the things of God
Jesus said, “...unless one is born again he cannot see the kingdom of God”
He added, “...unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God”

Jesus uses language that Nicodemus understood. First, he talks about birth. The analogy presses the point that just as no one can make themselves born physically, so no one can make themselves re-born spiritually

Secondly, the reality of being born of “water and the Spirit” is something Nicodemus would have connected to the prophet Ezekiel. In Ezekiel 36, the LORD promised that he would one day put his Spirit in his people and give them new hearts so that they would obey all his commands. This would cleanse them spiritually from all their unrighteousness.

Being a citizen of God’s kingdom demands a new birth. This is not an earthly birth but a spiritual one,  whereby a person comes to see clearly who Jesus is as Savior and LORD. Just as Jesus was conceived in Mary by the power of the Holy Spirit, so it is only by his same power that we can be made new. We may think we have life, but the Scripture is clear that until we find ourselves in Christ we don’t truly know what living is

This doesn’t mean that we will always be prosperous and care free. It means that no matter our circumstances, we have the freedom to live in the moment because we trust the One who has secured our future through his life, death, and resurrection. The life that Jesus promises is eternal; it is not bound by time or space and it lasts forever. And it comes by the same  power that conceived the Son of Heaven in Mary’s womb!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Life is filled with painful longing that is mixed with strange joy
title: Groaning With Joy

sections.text: Read

Pregnancy is filled with joyful anticipation and groaning. We long to see the face of the child that grows in the womb. As the day draws near the anticipation builds, but so does the anguish. Life is filled with painful longing that is mixed with strange joy. We experience almost daily the joy of what is on the horizon and the sorrow of longings unfulfilled. The things for which we often long (good as they may be) elude us either because they do not last or because they never come to be.
Israel longed for the Savior that had been promised in the garden. They believed God’s promise to grow Abraham’s family and bless the nations through his offspring
They remembered God’s covenant with David to have his heir reign on the throne forever
But through all the sin, suffering, and exile they wondered when God would make good on his promise. Israel groaned for centuries. They watched and waited.
Romans 8 says that creation itself groans. It longs to see the revealing of the sons (and daughters) of God

Do you long for this? Whatever else you may be longing for cannot compare to what God is waiting to reveal in you through the work of his Son Jesus. He is waiting for the day that he will reveal before all of creation who are his adopted children by faith in Jesus. Will you be in that number?

The apostle Peter wrote, “The Lord is not slow to fulfill his promise as some count slowness, but is patient toward you, not wishing that any should perish, but that all should reach repentance.” It may seem like God has forgotten his promise, but he is patiently waiting for sinners to turn from trusting in themselves and trust in his mercy displayed in Christ
The final reward is sure for those who groan, who long for him with all their hearts

C. S. Lewis famously said in his well-known book Mere Christianity, “If I find in myself a desire which no experience in this world can satisfy, the most probable explanation is that I was made for another world.” Advent is about waiting; it’s about longing; it’s about groaning. It’s about remembering that we were made to be satisfied in Christ alone. All our longings ultimately point to this reality. And we have the certainty that all our groaning will end because the One in whom we find the fullest satisfaction left his throne in Heaven, took on flesh, died for our sins, and rose to conquer death itself. We can groan with joy because Jesus has secured a future for those who love him and long for his return. It is a future that is beyond all comprehension or comparison. It is the forever for which we were made!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: The story of Mary and Joseph is a beautiful picture of the story of the whole Bible.
title: An Ordinary Couple, An Extraordinary Child

sections.text: Read

The story of Mary and Joseph is a beautiful picture of the story of the whole Bible. From the beginning, God’s plan was to create a world in which he would dwell with his people. And to fill the earth with his presence and glory, he started with a family. The fullest expression of God’s presence ultimately came in the person of Jesus Christ, and his birth came about through both ordinary and extraordinary means.

When Adam and Eve sinned in the garden, God did not turn his back on them. He made a promise to right their wrong, and he did so by causing their descendants to multiply. This family tree persisted until the promised Savior was born to the carpenter Joseph and the young Virgin Mary.

The fact that God sees fit to continue using ordinary people to work out his purposes in the world is encouraging. It means that he really can and does use anyone who will trust him in faith. It also means that he himself is consistent and trustworthy. Jesus could have come to earth as a full grown man, robed in majesty and power (of course this is how he will come the second time). But instead, he came as a baby. And though he was conceived miraculously by the Holy Spirit, he still came into the world the same way all other babies do.

We don’t have to wonder how to be a part of God’s plan. His will always centers around making Jesus known. And most often, he works through the natural and seemingly mundane to reveal himself. The beauty of Advent and the beauty of this life is that you can find Jesus in almost every aspect of life, if you’re truly looking for him. And when you find him there, celebrate and hold him up for others to see!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Jesus, being innocent, took our sin and shame...
title: Mercifully Just

sections.text: Read

The Savior of the world wasn’t born to a family with a trust fund. He wasn’t even born to a family of religious elites as we might expect. Jesus was born to a simple man who worked hard to provide for his family. He understood his role, even if it was a small one. What’s more, Joseph models the compassion and character of Christ.
When the Scripture says that Joseph was a just man

it doesn’t mean that he merely did what was morally acceptable according to the law or society. It means that he acted in the best interest of those who were most vulnerable. In his day, Joseph could have easily shamed Mary for being pregnant. No one knew for sure how she had conceived, and Joseph would have been viewed as right to divorce Mary on the basis of her perceived adultery. But he didn’t. In fact, to divorce her quietly was basically to heap Mary’s shame upon himself. Sound familiar?

Jesus is mercifully just. He showed the most profound compassion imaginable. Jesus, being innocent, took our sin and shame upon himself once and for all so that we could be adopted into God’s forever family! He became sin for us so that we could become the righteousness of God
God is just and therefore must punish sin. But God is simultaneously merciful in that rather than punish us he punished his own blameless Son in our place! Amen!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: Without God’s self-revelation there would be no Christmas.
title: God’s Self-Revelation

sections.text: Read

Without God’s self-revelation there would be no Christmas. Without God’s divine orchestration of events, Joseph would have missed out on being the earthly father of the Messiah. He was not in a hurry to divorce Mary, for surely he loved her. But as he considered what to do, the Lord met him in his confusion.  It was an angel of the Lord who came to Joseph and confirmed to him that the child growing in Mary’s womb was from God.
Without God’s divine action, Jesus would have been murdered by Herod. An angel of the Lord came to Joseph and in a dream to the wisemen in order to disclose Herod’s evil plot
Revelation 12 reveals that this plot was only an earthly manifestation of the cosmic scheme of the evil one himself

At every possible point of divergence, God overruled the tactics of the enemy. He shows us through the lives of Mary and Joseph that his plan will not be thwarted. And though Satan still tries to ruin the people of God, those who have truly understood who Jesus is and what he has done need not remain in darkness. We may not see him in the flesh now, but we believe in him because he has revealed himself and it is enough. He has revealed his plan, and we can trust him with it. Without it, there would be no Christ, no Christmas, and no hope! But praise God, he has revealed himself fully and finally in the person of Jesus Christ!

author: Jeremy Brown
cardDescription: I doubt anyone in their right mind would say they hate God.
title: The Subtle Way We Hate God

sections.text: Deuteronomy 7:9-11
sections.quote: Know therefore that the LORD your God is God, the faithful God who keeps covenant and steadfast love with those who love him and keep his commandments, to a thousand generations, and repays to their face those who hate him, by destroying them. He will not be slack with one who hates him. He will repay him to his face. You shall therefore be careful to do the commandment and the statutes and the rules that I command you today.

sections.text: I doubt anyone in their right mind would say they hate God. Most people in the world are religious, and many believe that God exists. Most of us will even say we love God. But ask yourself, “Do I love the true God as he has revealed himself in Scripture and history? Or do I simply love God as I have imagined him to be?” Notice in the verses above that to “hate God” is not to openly reject the concept of God altogether. It is to ignore, to disobey, or to disregard HIS WORD.

Deuteronomy describes those who love God as those who obey him and those who hate him as those who disobey his word. We understand this. Who among us truly feels loved by those who never listen to us? In the same way, to neglect to read, understand, delight in, and obey God’s word is to despise God himself. And God will have no pity on the one who finally rejects him by rejecting his word.

Some people once asked Jesus, “What must we do to be doing the works of God?” Jesus’ answer was simple….”This is the work of God, that you believe in the one whom he has sent” (John 6:29). To truly love God is to treasure Christ above everything else. And to truly treasure Christ is to hang on his every word! Jesus said, “If you love me you will keep my commands”

Many of us are guilty of loving the idea of Jesus without actually loving Jesus. Our obedience or lack thereof will always bear witness to who we really are. The good news is that God is slow to anger and abounding in steadfast love.
God is even more merciful than we have imagined him to be! He is always ready to forgive and restore those who turn to him in genuine repentance and faith.
1 John 1:9
sections.quote: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: FAMINE IN A HOUSE OF BREAD: Reflections on Advent from the story of Ruth
cardDescription: The story of Ruth and Naomi can guide us through the Advent season with hope and anticipation.
title: Famine In A House of Bread

sections.text: Ruth 1:1
sections.quote:
"In the days when the judges ruled there was a famine in the land,
and a man of Bethlehem in Judah went to sojourn in the country of Moab,
he and his wife and his two sons."

sections.text: Bethlehem. Literally, it means “house of bread” or “house of food.” How ironic, then, that this story should begin with a famine in a place where there was supposed to be plenty! But isn’t that the way life is? The places, people, and ideas that seem to promise so much eventually leave us disappointed and unsatisfied. Many of us will not experience a shortage of daily food, but everyone knows what it is to be anxious and empty. The story of Ruth reminds us that God makes and delivers on his promises even in the midst of hard times. Amid the groanings of this life we can find God’s promise of plenty. It’s when we are at the end of ourselves that we find that he is truly enough!

The story of Ruth and Naomi can guide us through the Advent season with hope and anticipation. We have all experienced the loss of loved ones and the grief that so plagues this season as we gather to a table that is increasingly emptier than it was a year before. And even if we enjoy the holidays, we know the let down that ensues as the festivities come to an end and we are left to ponder the marching of time once again. Ruth and Naomi’s story is our story. It begins with a famine in a land where there once was plenty. And though circumstances seem hopeless, there is a persistent echo of expectation....the promise that one day we will experience the absolute fullness for which we were created!

Famine has often played a major role in God’s plan of redemption. God used famine to force Jacob’s family to Egypt, where they would be saved by the brother they had once  forsaken. It was this very famine that put Joseph in a position to rule over all of Egypt where Israel flourished for hundreds of years.  The story of Ruth also begins with a famine. It begins at a time when God’s people are empty. But like the Christmas story we know so well, the story of Ruth ends with hands and hearts that are full, not only of grain but of a promised child. The story of Ruth is providentially intertwined with the story of Christ’s coming to Bethlehem. For the famine in this “house of bread” ends with the promise of the Bread of Life himself!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: FAMINE IN A HOUSE OF BREAD: Reflections on Advent from the story of Ruth
cardDescription: We sometimes find ourselves in desperate situations, not knowing what the future holds.
title: No Food, No Family

sections.text: Ruth 1:1-5
sections.quote:
"[1] In the days when the judges ruled there was a famine in the land, and a man of Bethlehem in Judah went to sojourn in the country of Moab, he and his wife and his two sons.
[2] The name of the man was Elimelech and the name of his wife Naomi, and the names of his two sons were Mahlon and Chilion. They were Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They went into the country of Moab and remained there.
[3] But Elimelech, the husband of Naomi, died, and she was left with her two sons.
[4] These took Moabite wives; the name of the one was Orpah and the name of the other Ruth. They lived there about ten years,
[5] and both Mahlon and Chilion died, so that the woman was left without her two sons and her husband."

sections.text: I sometimes wonder what Christmas was like during the time of the Great Depression. Most of us today have quaint thoughts of “the most wonderful time of the year,” but I have to imagine that for those living through national crisis, Christmas takes on a deeper meaning. And for those of us who have lost family and friends, we feel a measure of despair at Christmas time. So how are we to go on celebrating, even in the most dire circumstances? By remembering God’s promises and provision.
The time of the Judges was like the wild west, everyone doing what was right in their own eyes

It was at this time that Naomi and her family lived. It was in this already volatile situation that God brought about a famine in the region of Judah. And it was this desperate time that called for desperate measures, sending Naomi and her family to Moab of all places. This was no retreat to a more tranquil place. Moab was dark and dangerous, especially for a family from Judah. But they faced a choice: stay and starve or journey outside the comfort of home with a chance at survival.

The Bible doesn’t seem to condemn or condone Elimelech’s decision to migrate to Moab, but in the mind of a faithful Israelite reader, it would have struck them that a family could be so destitute as to have to go to a foreign, pagan country where people worshiped a god other than Yahweh. Some probably chose to die rather than go to such a place. And if the famine wasn’t bad enough, Naomi lost her husband and two sons and was left with no male descendants to carry on the family name or secure a future inheritance. In the ancient world, the thought of your family dying out was unacceptable. There was little-to-no thought given to individual identity. Your family name, as well as the material and spiritual inheritance that was handed down from generation to generation, was integral to the very identity of every person. When Naomi lost her sons, in a very real way she and any hope of her family persisting died with them. Yet, this was all part of God’s redemptive plan.

We sometimes find ourselves in desperate situations, not knowing what the future holds. Wether we are experiencing material poverty or not, we could call any season of loss a “famine of the soul.” We could look at the eroding culture around us and identify a “famine of righteousness,” such as existed in the days of the Judges. But we have the benefit of knowing that God uses all kinds of means to accomplish his purposes. Under normal circumstances, Elimelech would never have taken his family to Moab and Naomi’s sons would never have taken foreign wives. But here we see the beauty of God’s providence! God had made a promise to Abraham centuries before that in him all the families of the earth would be blessed (

). And though for Naomi this promise seems to be dissipating, God is about to make good on his promise once again in a most unlikely way. One of these Moabite women is about to become a key piece in God’s plan of redemption, not only for Naomi and her descendants but for the entire world! And Naomi, who now has no family, is about to become a matriarch of an even bigger and better one!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: FAMINE IN A HOUSE OF BREAD: Reflections on Advent from the story of Ruth
cardDescription: People say God’s timing is always perfect, but sometimes it’s hard to truly believe it.
title: Timing

sections.text: Ruth 1:6-7
sections.quote:
"[6] Then she arose with her daughters-in-law to return from the country of Moab, for she had heard in the fields of Moab that the LORD had visited his people and given them food.
[7] So she set out from the place where she was with her two daughters-in-law, and they went on the way to return to the land of Judah."

sections.text: People say God’s timing is always perfect, but sometimes it’s hard to truly believe it. I find myself wondering, why couldn’t the famine have ended before Naomi lost her husband and her sons? It seems so cruel. The famine drove this family from their home, and then after Naomi had lost everything dear to her, “the Lord visited his people and gave them food.”

This part of the story reminds me of another time when God seemed to be taking too long. Jesus and his disciples had just gotten word that Lazurus was near death. But rather than immediately traveling to heal Lazarus, Jesus waited. His stated reason for the delay is found in John 11:4, “But when Jesus heard it he said, ‘This illness does not lead to death. It is for the glory of God, so that the Son of God may be glorified through it.’” We know the rest of the story. Jesus arrived four days later, and then did the impossible. He raised Lazarus from the dead!

If Jesus had not waited, then he would never have raised Lazarus, and those present would never have experienced his power to save, even from death. If there had been no famine in Judah, Naomi’s family would never have gone to Moab; the kindness and loyalty of Ruth would not have been showcased. There would be no story of redemption. Whether at Christmas or any other part of the year, we can trust God’s timing. Even if we don’t like it. Even if it’s painful. We can remember the words of the prophet Isaiah,

sections.quote:
"[8] For my thoughts are not your thoughts,
neither are your ways my ways, declares the LORD.
[9] For as the heavens are higher than the earth,
so are my ways higher than your ways
and my thoughts than your thoughts."

sections.text: - Isaiah 55:8-9
No matter our circumstances, we can trust that God sees the end from the beginning. He loves us, sees us, and knows what is best for us. His timing is perfect!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: FAMINE IN A HOUSE OF BREAD: Reflections on Advent from the story of Ruth
cardDescription: Advent is an annual reminder that the deepest longings of our hearts are not yet satisfied but that God’s plan is leading us somewhere…
title: Honest Faith

sections.text: Ruth 1:8-14

sections.quote:
"[8] But Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, “Go, return each of you to her mother’s house. May the LORD deal kindly with you, as you have dealt with the dead and with me.
[9] The LORD grant that you may find rest, each of you in the house of her husband!” Then she kissed them, and they lifted up their voices and wept.
[10] And they said to her, “No, we will return with you to your people.”
[11] But Naomi said, “Turn back, my daughters; why will you go with me? Have I yet sons in my womb that they may become your husbands?
[12] Turn back, my daughters; go your way, for I am too old to have a husband. If I should say I have hope, even if I should have a husband this night and should bear sons,
[13] would you therefore wait till they were grown? Would you therefore refrain from marrying? No, my daughters, for it is exceedingly bitter to me for your sake that the hand of the LORD has gone out against me.”
[14] Then they lifted up their voices and wept again. And Orpah kissed her mother-in-law, but Ruth clung to her."

sections.text: We may be struck by Naomi’s brutal honesty. She says that her situation is “bitter” and that the “hand of the LORD has gone out against me.” I don’t think Naomi is being spiteful or disrespectful to God. In fact, I think she is exercising a measure of faith because while she is sorrowful over the situation, she is hopeful that God will deal kindly with Orpah and Ruth in providing husbands for them. She acknowledges that her loss is real and painful, but she knows it is under the control of a sovereign God. She is honest about the bitterness, but she has not forsaken her trust in God.

This kind of honest faith shouldn’t surprise those of us who read our Bibles. The psalms are full of lament over tragedy, persecution, and even sin. They are full of honest questioning and even doubt. Yet, most of these psalms end with resting in the faithfulness of God, knowing that he hears and that he cares. Psalm 77 is one such lament.

sections.quote:
"[7] “Will the Lord spurn forever,
and never again be favorable?
[8] Has his steadfast love forever ceased?
Are his promises at an end for all time?
[9] Has God forgotten to be gracious?
Has he in anger shut up his compassion?”"

sections.text: The psalmist feels forsaken by God. But then, he shows where his true faith lies. He reminds himself of God’s past faithfulness to his people and this renews his faith once again.

sections.quote:
"[11] I will remember the deeds of the LORD;
yes, I will remember your wonders of old.
[12] I will ponder all your work,
and meditate on your mighty deeds.
[13] Your way, O God, is holy.
What god is great like our God?
[14] You are the God who works wonders;
you have made known your might among the peoples.
[15] You with your arm redeemed your people,
the children of Jacob and Joseph."

sections.text: We need honest faith like this. It does us no good to pretend like everything is fine when it’s not. Acknowledging that life is hard is part of the way we deal with the difficulty. And we shouldn’t be too quick to try to ease someone else’s pain either. Sometimes, like Naomi and her grief-stricken daughters-in-law, we need to sit and weep with those who weep

But we also need to acknowledge that God is always in control and always good, even when life is hard. As Job said to his wife when she rebuked him for his steadfast faith, “Should we receive good from God and not calamity?”
True faith is not faith that pretends. It is faith that rests in the goodness and sovereignty of God, especially when the road has been hard and the way forward doesn’t seem clear.

Advent is an annual reminder that the deepest longings of our hearts are not yet satisfied but  that God’s plan is leading us somewhere…to a place and time when we will be completely whole. Though Naomi’s story in this moment was bitter, it will end with sweetness she could never have imagined. Though she and Ruth shed tears together over their loss, their family heritage will be restored a hundredfold.

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: FAMINE IN A HOUSE OF BREAD: Reflections on Advent from the story of Ruth
cardDescription: As we observe the steadfast devotion that Ruth exhibits toward her mother-in-law throughout the story, we can see a glimpse of God’s covenant love toward us...
title: Covenant Faithfulness

sections.quote:
"[15] And she said, “See, your sister-in-law has gone back to her people and to her gods; return after your sister-in-law.”
[16] But Ruth said, “Do not urge me to leave you or to return from following you. For where you go I will go, and where you lodge I will lodge. Your people shall be my people, and your God my God.
[17] Where you die I will die, and there will I be buried. May the LORD do so to me and more also if anything but death parts me from you.”
[18] And when Naomi saw that she was determined to go with her, she said no more."

sections.text: It would have been reasonable for Ruth to go back to her own people, to stay where she had been all her life and try to make a new life in a familiar place. This is what Orpah did, and it was the sensible choice. But Ruth represents what it means to exercise bold faith. She is determined that she will not return to Moab, but she will brave whatever future awaits Naomi. This is a huge turning point in the story as it shows Ruth’s steadfast love for her mother-in-law. She says those climactic words, “Where you go I will go….Your people shall be my people, and your God my God….Where you die I will die, and there will I be buried”
With these words, Ruth binds herself to Naomi through an oath that invokes the name of Yahweh
In doing this, she is truly claiming Yahweh as her God and pledging herself to Naomi in covenant love.

We may have thought this was a love story between a man and a woman. In actuality, it showcases the steadfast love between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law. Ruth’s expression of loyal love is a small echo of the covenant love of God. In fact, the language Ruth uses to bind herself to Naomi is similar to the language that the LORD used to bind himself to Israel

This is striking! Don’t forget that Ruth was a Moabite. She had more immediate prospects for survival if she stayed in her homeland. To return to the land of Judah with Naomi was a great risk to her own future. There was no guarantee that she would find a husband or even have a life. But she loved Naomi with a sacrificial kind of love. And in expressing her love for Naomi, she simultaneously confessed her trust in the LORD.

What would cause Ruth to do this? It can only be explained in light of the larger story. God’s plan for Naomi and Ruth was to use them to preserve his covenant with Abraham and bring about a promised descendant who would be the ruler and savior of the world

Ruth’s loyalty toward Naomi is ultimately a picture of God’s faithfulness toward his people. As we observe the steadfast devotion that Ruth exhibits toward her mother-in-law throughout the story, we can see a glimpse of God’s covenant love toward us, as he prepares the way for the coming of our promised Savior!
